source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_031_chunk1
evidence_span: Three original Zircaloy-2 clad blanket fuel bundles from the pressurizedwater reactor (PWR) at the Shippingport Atomic Power Station were discharged after continuous exposure during Cores 1 and 2

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_031_chunk1
evidence_span: uniform light gray (posttransition) corrosion products with no evidence of unexpected corrosion deterioration

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_031_chunk1
evidence_span: All corrosion films were found to be tightly adherent to the underlying cladding

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_031_chunk1
evidence_span: significantly greater end-of-life rod average oxide film thicknesses when compared with corresponding values calculated from the timetemperature history

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_031_chunk1
evidence_span: pretransition region and the time to transition are in adequate agreement with the empirical equations generated from the ex-reactor data

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_031_chunk1
evidence_span: significant acceleration of the posttransition corrosion rate due to the irradiation exposure

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_031_chunk1
evidence_span: Multipurpose Extended Life Blanket Assembly cladding in the mid-sections of the rods (α microstructure) was found to have corroded at a rate that is approximately 25 percent greater than the corresponding welded end cap regions β quenched structure

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_031_chunk1
evidence_span: total hydrogen content of the cladding was less than that calculated from the ex-reactor expressions

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_031_chunk1
evidence_span: hydrogen pickup per unit weight gain is two to three times greater in the late posttransition period than that observed in the early posttransition region

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_031_chunk1

evidence_span: The development of texture during deformation of zirconium alloys has received much attention and is generally understood.

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_031_chunk11
evidence_span: Both slip and twinning occur as the reorientation of basal poles of the hexagonal (hcp) structure is biased toward the compression direction.

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_031_chunk11
evidence_span: The material flow during deformation is clearly important in determining texture.

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_031_chunk11
evidence_span: For tube reduction, the relative wall thickness reduction (radial deformation) and diameter reduction (circumferential deformation) determine the final distribution of basal poles.

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_031_chunk11
evidence_span: The curvature of the tool used in tube reducing has a strong influence on texture
